text: random idea i had over the weekend: what if we recreated the mountain room in our new reception lounge
i like that
only if we can reupholster the wingback chair as Ewald and I had originally envisioned
and we have more mountains
yes yes yes
i was also hoping we’d carry some element of mountain over to 811. so much so that i started looking for paint by number mountains on etsy.
yessss
maybe we should swap out boho lounge for mountain lounge
ᴛʙʜ ɴᴏᴛ ᴀ ʜᴜɢᴇ ғᴀɴ ᴏғ ᴛʜᴇ ʙᴏʜᴏ ʟᴏᴜɴɢᴇ
:grimacing:
armchairs instead of bean bags? yes *please*.
i’m not sure what we’re referring to really, but the thought of working in a bean bag makes me feel weird
<@U04JZANJF|amanda> uploaded a file: <https://uncorked.slack.com/files/amanda/F0PJKPY68/screen_shot_2016-02-29_at_3.29.26_pm.png|Screen Shot 2016-02-29 at 3.29.26 PM.png>
elk proposed a boho lounge
i dont think anyone is a fan of the boho lounge
was thinking entry lounge because there will be walls there instead of windows

My immediate reaction to the boho lounge was not exactly favorable, but the idea is kind of growing on me. I actually like that it is not even close to what I would expect. The Persian rug/tapestry patterns specifically have become more intriguing over time.

I think it’s more that it gives a refreshing escape to an unexpected aesthetic space, the same way Airbnb had all their tiny houses designed around multicultural living spaces. I know we’re not Airbnb but I am thankful Elk is proposing something that’s not just ultra modern wood/metal/concrete and minimalist accents.

Just my two cents
yes, i like the idea of comfort and color, while i don’t particularly relate to the word “boho"
boho reminds me of hobo
but I like the low ground approach to a room, even if the color palette were slightly different

I may be getting a little introspective/sentimental now…

but as I’m thinking about this, I believe the range of diversity Uncorked has as a team of people is one of my favorite parts about working here and a great source of pride for me in being a part of it. Not that a boho lounge is the format for representing it, but I would love for our space to demonstrate that very special part of our DNA. The more I think about it the more it makes me want something unexpected.
May be more accurate to say bobo: <http://www.theguardian.com/theobserver/2000/may/28/focus.news1>

attachments.title: Are you a BOurgeois BOhemian?
attachments.text: It's hard to miss them: The epitome of casual 'geek chic' and organised within the warranty of their Palm Pilots, they sip labour-intensive café lattes, chat on sleek cellphones and ponder the road to enlightenment. In the US they worry about the environment as they drive their gas-guzzling sports utility vehicles to emporiums of haute design to buy a $50 titanium spatula; they think about their tech stocks as they explore speciality shops for Tibetan artefacts in Everest-worthy hiking boots. They think nothing of laying out $5 for a wheatgrass muff, much less $500 for some alternative rejuvenation at the day-spa - but don't talk about raising their taxes.
attachments.fallback: the Guardian: Are you a BOurgeois BOhemian?

text: But I personally agree that something other than wood/metal/concrete is refreshing and I like the lower profile of the room.
clown chic

>>> Combining the free-spirited, artistic rebelliousness of the bohemian beatnik or hippie with the worldly ambitions of their bourgeois corporate forefathers, the Bobo is a comfortable contortion of caring capitalism.
